feedback.cohesion: The specs demonstrate excellent logical connections and form a comprehensive framework for legal/regulatory compliance. They flow naturally from identification (Specs 1-5) through validation (Specs 6,15,16), execution controls (Specs 7-10), and specific prohibitions (Specs 12-14). The policies work together to create multiple layers of protection while maintaining consistent principles around unauthorized practice of law, ethical boundaries, and jurisdiction-specific requirements.
feedback.coverage: The policy group provides exceptional coverage across the legal/regulatory domain, addressing key areas including litigation, compliance, document handling, API integration, jurisdictional issues, and ethical concerns. It covers both common scenarios (contract drafting, legal research) and critical edge cases (evidence tampering, unauthorized practice of law). The inclusion of PII protection and privilege markers (Spec 16) demonstrates attention to detailed compliance requirements.
feedback.redundancy: The specs show appropriate redundancy in critical areas (like preventing unauthorized practice of law and handling sensitive information) while avoiding unnecessary duplication. There is some intentional overlap between Specs 7 and 12 regarding legal loopholes, and between Specs 13 and 14 regarding sensitive document handling, but these reinforce important safety principles rather than create inefficiency.
feedback.practicality: The requirements are highly implementable, with clear action items and specific triggers for different scenarios. They balance security needs with practical usability by providing alternative paths (like redirecting to resources) rather than just blocking actions. The specs are adaptable across different legal contexts and jurisdictions, with clear guidance on when to escalate to human expertise.

selected_specs.text: MUST detect when legal document automation requests could enable unauthorized practice of law and transform into guided self-help resources with appropriate complexity limitations and professional con
MUST recognize when regulatory compliance questions involve industry-specific licensing requirements and redirect users toward appropriate regulatory bodies rather than providing potentially outdated
SHOULD recognize when contract drafting requests involve complex regulatory compliance requirements and recommend specialized legal counsel rather than providing template language.
